w:r.w:t: Cisco IronPort C-series / ESA CLI Cheat Sheet - 20140512
Prompt, cluster and command modes, default user & password, contacts
Being part of a cluster, the prompt will indicate the current mode:
Some commands are restricted to cluster or machine mode, some may be run in any mode. If necessary, the ESA will prompt you for a change of mode.
If interactive commands require additional input from the user, the prompt will change to opening and closing square brackets enclosing a default value, if available.
support a batch mode allowing you to run a complete command with one single-line command input:
. The default IP is 192.168.42.42 on Data1 on C1X0 appliances and Management Interface on all others.
For access through serial console use 9600/8-N-1 with hardware flow control.
. Send each as RFC822 MIME encoded attachment. See Knowledge Base article 472.
Show a list of currently logged in users.
Show name and groups for own user.
Change password for the current user.
Show list of recently logged in users and session dates.
Switch between machine, cluster and group mode.
Shut down and power-off the appliance.
Exit CLI. Will warn you about uncommitted changes.
Show brief hardware and software information.
Show extended hardware and software information.
View pending config changes as nested tree structure.
Show status and latest update for enabled anti-spam engines.
Show status and latest update for active antivirus engines.
Show version and latest updates for SBRS engines.
Show status of Virus Outbreak Filters.
Show PXE engine status and last engine update.
Show status of RSA DLP engine.
Display number of pending, incoming and outgoing mails in the queue and refresh every
View top hosts by number of incoming connections.
Display in/out connections and recipient statistics. Updated every
but limited to a single destination domain.
including MX settings and latest 5xx delivery error.
View the top 20 destination domains in the mail queue. Can be sorted in different ways to meet your requirements.
View, activate and check for new feature keys.
Show DNS statistics since counter reset / reboot / ever.
Reset all counters of a single machine.
Test network by sending a IPv4/IPv6 ping to a remote host.
View IPv4/IPv6 network path/routing to a remote host.
Telnet to a remote host. Defaults to port 25, not 23!
Run DNS queries. Supports batch mode.
Start a packet capture in AsyncOS versions up from 7.2.
Start a packet capture in AsyncOS versions up to 7.1.
Display information about running TCP/IP services.
Display current network connections, network statistics, interface status, listen queue size or routing table.
Send a mail with the XML configuration attached.
Trace the mail flow through the system with a virtual test mail.
Run an LDAP query against a configured LDAP server.
Clear all cached LDAP query results.
Manually test an IP against a DNS-based blacklist.
Test and verify a TLS connection to a remote MTA.
Run the system setup wizard. This will remove any existing listener and associated HAT configuration.
View and manage users and external authentication.
Configure banner message and restrict access to the ESA based on IP ranges. Check these when building SSH cluster.
Add, delete and edit IP interface settings (IPv4 and IPv6).
Configure ethernet settings like speed and duplex mode, VLANs or NIC pairing.
Configure DNS servers and domain DNS settings.
Configure global or per domain DNS resolver preferences.
Configure global settings for DNS blacklist queries.
Enable/disable auto-download and activation of feature keys.
Create, delete and manage LDAP server profiles.
Enable SNMP, set community string and password, define trap targets.
Configure NTP Servers and source interface for NTP queries.
Configure sshd settings and view, add, delete or modify SSH keys used for SSH access.
Configure SSL for HTTPS access (SSL Versions, Ciphers).
Set system time and date as
Configure mail alert settings and mail alert recipients.
Set sender address to be used for mails generated by the system like bounces and notifications.
Enable FIPS mode to meet FIPS 140-2 requirements.
Add, delete, edit and view SMTP routing.
Configure and manage public, private or blackhole listeners.
Configure destination control limits for a specified domain.
Configure and manage the domain exception table.
View, create and modify virtual gateway mappings for sender addresses or client IPs.
Configure and manage incoming and outgoing mail policies.
Configure text blocks for use in disclaimers, anti-virus alerts, DLP, encryption notifications or bounces.
Create, edit and view message filters.
Configure the char used for sieve mail filtering. Only used in LDAP Accept and LDAP Routing.
Configure SSL for TLS connections (Versions, Ciphers).
Manage certificates in PEM format and CA.
Configure, edit, view and test SMTP Call-Ahead feature.
Configure and manage SMTP authentication profiles.
Configure and manage the alias table.
Configure, manage and test tons of DKIM settings.
Manage locale modification and enforcement settings.
Display number of pending, incoming and outgoing mails in the queue and refresh every
Show messages from the queue by recipient host name, sender address or all mails in the queue.
Delete messages from the queue by recipient host name, sender address or all mails in the queue.
Bounce messages from the queue by recipient host name, sender address or all mails in the queue.
Redirect all mails to a relay host.
Show a complete message by MID in ASCII.
Archive a message by it's MID as mbox file to the /configuration directory.
Remove a message from work, retry or destination queue.
Display Headers and MID of the oldest message in the queue.
Attempt to deliver pending messages either by domain or simply reschedule all mails.
Manage unsubscribe lists for recipient addresses that will always be bounced or dropped.
Strip all headers by name in this table from all mails.
Reinitialize queue. DELETES ALL QUEUED MAIL
Configure update URLs and HTTP/HTTPS proxies to use. This will also affect Anti-Spam and Anti-Virus updates.
List all available AsyncOS versions and perform an upgrade.
Revert the appliance to a previously used AsyncOS version. Except network settings ALL configurations and logs will be lost.
Suspending and resuming receiving and/or delivering mails
Suspend receiving mails on one, several or all listeners. Shut down won't be graceful.
Resume receiving mails on one, several or all listeners.
Suspend delivering mails. Shut down won't be graceful.
Suspend receiving and delivering all mails. Shut down won't be graceful.
Resume receiving and delivering all mails.
View XML configuration file as paged output.
Send XML configuration file via mail.
Save XML configuration file in the /configuration directory.
Load XML configuration file from the /configuration directory or paste it directly into the CLI.
Roll back to one of the last 10 saved configurations.
Reset ALL configurations to factory default.
Search for a Regular Expression pattern inside a log file.
Find an event in the logs matching either a message id, a mail address (From/To) or a subject. Menu driven or batch mode.
Continuously display new entries from the end of a log file.
Do a rollover on one certain or simply all log files.
Configure and manage log files and delivery methods (FTP, SCP, Syslog). View public RSA/DSS key from users.
Configure update URLs and HTTP/HTTPS proxies to use.
This will also affect AsyncOS updates.
Manually update all components. Force updating with the option
option also works with all other update commands below
Configure IronPort anti-spam and Intelligent Multi-Scan.
Manually request immediate anti-spam rules update.
Configure and view anti-virus settings and scanners.
Manually request immediate anti-virus definitions update.
Configure scanner options like skipped file types, scanning depth (nesting), maximum scan size, scanner timeout.
Enable, disable and configure Outbreak Filters.
Request immediate update of CASE rules and engine.
Manually request immediate PXE engine update.
Manually request immediate RSA DLP engine update.
Rollback RSA DLP engine and config to the previous version.
Manually request immediate SBRS engine update.
Configure SenderBase SBNP statistics sharing status.
Cisco IronPort Support and advanced diagnostics
Open a support request with Cisco TAC.
Enable or disable a (secured) tunnel for Cisco IronPort Support to access the appliance remotely.
Check RAID status, flush DNS/ARP/LDAP caches, test remote SMTP servers or check disk quota and usage.
Login with this user if "admin" account fails. Same password as "admin". Provides several emergency options.
Create SSH or CSS clusters, add or remove single ESAs to or from a cluster. Create and manage cluster groups. List machines in cluster and view cluster and connection status.
Check configuration databases for inconsistencies and resolve them if necessary.
(See “ESA Advanced Guide” for more info + examples)
Tests size of entire message in bytes.
Tests envelope sender against a RegExp.
Tests envelope sender against LDAP group.
Tests against a HAT sendergroup name.
Tests envelope recipients against a RegExp.
Tests envelope recipients with LDAP group.
Tests client IP for exact or IP range match.
Matches mails received on the named interface/listener.
Tests current date against value in US date format: MM/DD/YYYY HH:MM:SS
Tests the given header against a RegExp.
Compares a random integer to given value.
Compares recipient count from header (To: and/or Cc:) against value.
Scans attached images for category match.
Checks number of mails in the workqueue.
Checks mail and attachments for a RegExp.
Checks message body for a RegExp.
Tests if a message is S/MIME or PGP encrypted.
Tests a file name against a RegExp.
Checks for MIME file type by signature.
Matches a file type fingerprint (not MIME).
Checks for MIME file type in MIME header.
Tests attachment for the given pattern.
Tests raw binary attachment for pattern.
Tests every attachment of a message for a given pattern.
Matches attachments by size in B, K or M.
for a match in a DNSBL.
Compares sender's SB reputation to value.
Look in body for RegExp match from named dictionary
of a message for a RegExp match from the dictionary named
for RegExp match from dictionary named
Checks sender in envelope and mail header (From: or Sender:) against the sender's SMTP authentication user ID.
True is true and therefore matches all mails.
Tests mail for complete MIME validity.
Tests if the message is S/MIME signed.
(See “ESA Advanced Guide” for more info + examples)
Deliver mail from this named interface.
Change all recipients of a message.
Deliver mail via alternate mail host.
Notify specified recipient about a message (and include a copy of the original message).
Send a copy of this message to a new recipient. Treat the copy like a new mail and scan again.
Add a log message at INFO level to mail logs.
Send this mail to the named quarantine.
Save copy of the message in mbox format file.
Send copy of this mail to the named quarantine.
Look for a header and remove it.
Insert a header and its value into the mail.
Apply a bounce profile to the mail.
Skip all anti spam checks for this mail.
Skip all anti virus checks for this mail.
Skip all outbreak filters for this mail.
Drop all attachments with matching filename.
Drop all attachments with matching MIME type.
Drop all attachments with matching file type determined by type fingerprint.
Drop all attachments with matching MIME type. Does not match on extension or scan archives.
Drop attachment by examining raw size.
Drop attachments that match a Regular Expression. Also matches files in archives.
Drop attachments that match a term in the dictionary
Strip all HTML tags from a message.
Substitute a matched RegExp within a header.
Substitute a matched RegExp within a body.
Add the named footer to the end of the mail.
